summary.title: Introduction to Information Science and Technology
summary.description: This course introduces students to the world of IST across a broad range of topics. Topics include history of computing, computing in society, career paths in computing and the use of computers in the workplace.

course-outcomes.outcome: Understand the context of computing in the current society, including the business place.
Understand the social consequences of modern computing technology and the way it is used.
Understand the historical development of computing technology and its impact on current decisions.
Make informed decisions about upcoming choices towards a computing major and technical electives.
Understand the resources available to and expectations and responsibilities of a college student at Vermont Technical College.

course-content.summary: The details of the course may vary somewhat over time to stay topical and reflect current issues and interests. Typically, the bulk of the class will cover several broad themes. For each of these themes, the class should consider the historical, social, ethical, business and technological implications and development. In addition, the course will ensure that all students are exposed to key considerations of being a student at Vermont Technical College.
course-content.topic: Drivers of computing (modeling the natural world, counting and computing, and information management).
Enabled technologies (telecommunication and networking, privacy and secrecy, media, optionally operations research).
Foundations of computing (what is thinking, natural and artificial intelligence, robotics).
Appropriate behavior in and out of classrooms.

outline.additional-information: This course serves as a breadth first introduction to the field of computing for all IST students.
outline.internal-comments: This course replaced HIS-1260, History of IT, which was a required first semester course for all IST students. As this course is taken by every first semester fall student, it incorporates the current Freshman Orientation material as well.
